What is the primary reason for studying SID & STAR charts before and during a flight?
optionA: To check for any changes to the published procedures.
optionB: To ensure the correct lateral and vertical profiles are flown.
optionC: To ensure that noise abatement procedures are observed.
optionD: In order to take account of any pre-planned flight deviations before the flight.

question: On an instrument approach chart,a minimum sector altitude (MSA) is defined in relation to a radio navigation facility. Without any particular specification on distance,this altitude is valid to:

optionA: the airway base is 3 500 ft MSL.
optionB: the airway is a low level link route 2 100 ft - 3 500 ft MSL.
optionC: the minimum obstruction clearance altitude (MOCA) is 3 500 ft.
optionD: the minimum enroute altitude (MEA) is 3 500 ft.

question: Unless otherwise stated on charts for standard instrument departures the depicted routes are defined as:

FL330 M 0.78 Ts: -60°C HWC: 5 kts

optionA: the minimum flight level is FL80.
optionB: the floor of the airway is at 8 000 ft.
optionC: the altitude of the highest obstacle is 8 000 ft.
optionD: the minimum safe altitude is 8 000 ft.

question: An airway is marked 5000 2900a. The notation 5000 is the:

optionA: In case of VFR flights during the day.
optionB: In case for a flight with an unexpected diversion.
optionC: If safe force landing areas are always available during flight.
optionD: Final reserve fuel is for emergency only therefore it is prohibited to plan the usage of such fuel.

question: Integrated range curves or tables are presented in the Aeroplane Operations Manuals. Their purpose is:
optionA: to determine the flight time for a certain leg under consideration of temperature deviations.
optionB: to determine the still air distance for wind components varying with altitude.
optionC: to determine the optimum speed considering the fuel cost as well as the time related cost of the aeroplane.
optionD: to determine the fuel consumption for a certain still air distance considering the decreasing fuel flow with decreasing mass.

question: The quantity of fuel which is calculated to be necessary for a jet aeroplane to fly IFR from departure aerodrome to the destination aerodrome is 5 352 kg. Fuel consumption in holding mode is 6 000 kg/hr. Alternate fuel is 4 380 kg. Contingency should be 5% of Trip Fuel. What is the minimum required quantity of fuel which should be on board at take-off?

The overhead distance from A to B is 45 NM at which you travel at 180 kts. The fuel flow per hour during cruise and holding is 2 700 kg and the additional fuel considered for climb,descent and approach equals 500 kg. What is your contingency fuel?
Contingency,which is used for flight planning purposes,corresponds to a value of 5% of the:

A pilot is preparing a commercial flight but during the planning phase the latest weather update at the destination aerodrome leads to a change of the runway which in turn results to a more time consuming arrival section. What will happen to the planned trip fuel?
optionA: It will not change because it is not part of the arrival procedure.
optionB: It will not change because the arrival fuel consists of a fixed quantity.
optionC: The pilot could update the trip fuel,but he/she does not have to update the contingency fuel because it covers such changes during the planning phase.
optionD: It has to be updated correspondingly.

question: Which of the following statements is correct if you compare the integrated range procedure with the average fuel flow procedure?
optionA: The average fuel flow procedure is more precise and considers different fuel consumption during different flight sectors.
optionB: The integrated range procedure is a much easier and faster method when calculating the necessary trip fuel.
optionC: The average fuel flow procedure is more precise and considers fuel consumption during different flight sectors.
optionD: The average fuel flow procedure allows a very precise monitoring of the fuel for short and long haul flights.

The commander is responsible for the fuel. What is true regarding a diversion of a commercial flight?
optionA: The remaining fuel should be at least the same as the amount which is required to reach at least two different aerodromes where a safe landing can be made. One of them can be the aerodrome of departure.
optionB: The remaining fuel should be at least the same amount as the required fuel to reach an aerodrome where a safe landing can be made,with final reserve fuel remaining.
optionC: A diversion is an unplanned event so the commander is not responsible concerning this amount of fuel.
optionD: The remaining fuel should be at least the same amount as the required fuel to return to the aerodrome of departure.

question: Following in-flight depressurization,a turbine powered aeroplane is forced to divert to an enroute alternate airfield."If actual flight conditions are as forecast,the minimum quantity of fuel remaining on arrival at the airfield will be:
optionA: laid down by the operator,with the quantity being specified in the operating manual.
optionB: at least equivalent to 45 minutes flying time.
optionC: at least equivalent to 30 minutes flying time.
optionD: at least equivalent to the quantity required to fly to another aerodrome in the event that weather conditions so require.

optionA: Zero Fuel Mass plus Final Reserve Fuel and Alternate Fuel.
optionB: Zero Fuel Mass plus Final Reserve Fuel.
optionC: Zero Fuel Mass plus Final Reserve Fuel and Contingency Fuel.

question: The final reserve fuel for aeroplanes with turbine engines is:

optionB: fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions.
optionC: fuel to fly for 60 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions.
optionD: fuel to fly for 45 minutes at holding speed at 1 000 ft (300 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions.

question: An operator shall ensure that calculation of usable fuel for an IFR flight with a turbojet aeroplane for which no destination alternate is required includes,taxi fuel,Trip Fuel,contingency fuel and fuel to fly for:
optionA: 45 minutes at holding speed at 450 m above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions.
optionC: 45 minutes plus 10% of the flight time planned to be spent at cruising level or two hours whichever is less.
optionD: 45 minutes at holding speed at 450 m above MSL in standard conditions.

optionC: To increase the safety of the flight.

question: A jet aeroplane has a cruising fuel consumption of 4 060 kg/hr,and 3 690 kg/hr during holding. If the destination is an isolated airfield,the aeroplane must carry,in addition to contingency reserves,additional fuel of:

optionB: contingency fuel by adding contingency only from the burnoff between the decision airport and destination.
optionC: contingency fuel by adding contingency only from the burnoff between decision point and destination.

question: Mark the correct statement. If a decision point procedure is applied for flight planning:
optionA: a destination alternate is not required.
optionB: the Trip Fuel to the destination aerodrome is to be calculated via the decision point.
optionC: the Trip Fuel to the destination aerodrome is to be calculated via the suitable enroute alternate.
optionD: the fuel calculation is based on a contingency fuel from departure aerodrome to the decision point.

optionA: has a certified Landing Mass greater than or equal to 136 000 kg.
optionB: requires a runway length of at least 2000 m at Maximum Certified Take-off Mass.

optionD: has a certified Take-Off Mass greater than or equal to 140 000 lbs.

question: In the ATS flight plan item 15 (cruising speed),when not expressed as a Mach number,cruising speed is expressed as:
On an ATC flight plan,the letter Y is used to indicate that the flight is carried out under the following flight rules:

question: When an ATS flight plan is submitted for a flight outside designated ATS routes,points included in item 15 (route) should not normally be at intervals of more than:

Which wake turbulence category should be entered in item 9 of the ATS flight plan?
In the appropriate box of a flight plan,for endurance,one must indicate the time corresponding to:
optionA: the required fuel for the flight plus the alternate and 45 minutes.
optionB: the total usable fuel on board minus reserve fuel.
optionC: the required fuel for the flight.
optionD: the total usable fuel on board.

question: On an ATC flight plan,to indicate that you will overfly the waypoint TANGO at 350 kts at flight level 280,you will write:

optionB: include an indication of the aircraft type.

question: For the purposes of item 9 (wake turbulence category) of the ATS flight plan,an aircraft with a maximum certificated Take-off Mass of 62 000 kg is:
If no ICAO identifier has been attributed to an alternate airport (box 16) of a flight plan form:
optionA: write ZZZZ in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) ALTN/ followed by the name of the airport.
optionB: write ZZZZ in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) DEST/ followed by the name of the airport.
optionC: write XXXX in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) ALTN/ followed by the name of the airport.
optionD: write XXXX in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) DEST/ followed by the name of the airport.

optionA: full name of VOR,true bearing and distance in kilometres.
optionB: VOR ident,magnetic bearing and distance in kilometres.
optionC: VOR ident,true bearing and distance in kilometres.
optionD: VOR ident,magnetic bearing and distance in nautical miles.

question: If your destination airport has no ICAO indicator,in the appropriate box of your ATC flight plan,you write:

When completing an ATS flight plan for a flight commencing under IFR but possibly changing to VFR,the letters entered in item 8 (flight rules) would be:

optionC: the time overhead the first reporting point after take-off.
optionD: the time at which the flight plan is filed.

question: In the ATS flight plan,for a non-scheduled flight which of the following letters should be entered in item 8 (type of flight):

Which of the following statements is (are) correct with regard to the operation of flight planning computers?
1) The computer can file the ATC flight plan.
2) In the event of inflight re-routing the computer produces a new plan.
On a VFR flight plan,the total estimated time is:
optionA: the estimated time from take-off to overhead the destination airport,plus 15 minutes.
optionB: the estimated time required from take-off to arrive over the destination airport
optionC: the estimated time from take-off to landing at the alternate airport.
optionD: the estimated time from engine start to landing at the destination airport.

question:
Which of the following statements is (are) correct with regard to the advantages of computer flight plans?
1) The computer can file the ATC flight plan.
2) Wind data used by the computer is always more up-to-date than that available to the pilot.
Prior to an IFR flight,when filling in the ICAO flight plan,the time information which should be entered in box 16 "Total estimated time" is the time elapsed from:
optionA: taxiing until the IAF (Initial Approach Fix) of the destination aerodrome.
optionB: take-off until reaching the IAF (Initial Approach Fix) of the destination aerodrome.
optionC: taxi-out prior to take-off until taxiing after landing.

question: In the ATS flight plan item 10 (equipment),the letter to indicate the carriage of a serviceable transponder - mode A (4 digits-4096 codes) and mode C,is:
When a pilot fills in a flight plan,he/she must indicate the wake turbulence category. This category is a function of which mass?

Which of the following statements is (are) correct with regard to computer flight plans?
1) The computer takes account of bad weather on the route and adds extra fuel.
2) The computer calculates alternate fuel sufficient for a missed approach,climb,cruise,descent and approach and landing at the destination alternate.
The "Estimated Total Time" in block 16 of a VFR flight plan is the estimated time:
optionA: required by the aircraft from take-off to arrive overhead the destination airport.
optionB: of endurance at cruising power taking into account pressure and temperature on that day.
optionC: required by the aircraft from brake release at take-off until landing.
optionD: required by the aircraft from the moment it moves by its own power until it stops at the end of the flight (block time).

question: When completing an ATS flight plan for a European destination,clock times are to be expressed in:

optionA: STARS should be entered but not SIDs.
optionB: neither SID nor STAR should be entered.
optionC: SIDs should be entered but not STARs.
optionD: both should be entered in the ATS plan where appropriate.

question: When completing an ATS flight plan,an elapsed time (item 16) of 1 hrs 55 min should be entered as:

optionA: an estimate may be entered but that number may not subsequently be exceeded.
optionB: "TBN" (to be notified) may be entered in the relevant box.
optionC: the plan may not be filed until the information is available.
optionD: the plan should be filed with the relevant box blank.

For a repetitive flight plan (RPL) to be used,flights must take place on a regular basis on at least:
Repetitive flight plans (RPLs) shall be used for flights operated regularly on the same day(s) of consecutive weeks and:
optionA: on at least ten (10) occasions or every day over a period of at least 10 consecutive days.
optionD: on at least ten (10) occasions or every day over a period of at least 20 consecutive days

question: A repetitive flight plan (RPL) is filed for a scheduled flight: Paris Orly to Angouleme,Paris Orly as alternate. Following heavy snow falls,Angouleme airport will be closed at the expected time of arrival. The airline decides before departure to plan a re-routing of that flight to Limoges.
optionA: The RPL must be cancelled for that day and a specific flight plan has to be filed.
optionB: The pilot-in-command must advise ATC of his intention to divert to Limoges at least 15 minutes before the planned time of arrival.
optionC: The airline's Operations Department has to transmit a change in the RPL at the ATC office,at least half an hour before the planned time of departure.
optionD: It is not possible to plan another destination and the flight has to be simply cancelled that day (scheduled flight and not chartered).

question: Change from IFR to VFR will always take place only:
optionA: when the aircraft is leaving controlled airspace during VMC.
optionB: on the initiative of the aircraft commander.
optionC: as instructed by an air traffic control unit.
optionD: at the clearance limit,irrespective of the weather conditions.

question:
From the options given below select those flights which require ATC flight plan notification:
1) any Public Transport flight.
2) any IFR flight.
3) any flight which is to be carried out in regions which are designated to ease the provision of the Alerting Service or the operations of Search and Rescue.
4) most cross-border flights.
5) any flight which involves overflying water.

It is possible,in flight,to:
1) file an IFR flight plan.
2) modify an active IFR or VFR flight plan.
3) cancel an active VFR flight plan.
4) close an active VFR flight plan.

If a pilot lands at an aerodrome other than the destination aerodrome specified in the flight plan,he must ensure that the ATS unit at the destination aerodrome is informed within a certain number of minutes of his planned ETA at destination. This number of minutes is:
The appropriate ATS unit has to be informed in case of inadvertent changes from a Flight plan:
optionA: if the time estimate for the next reporting point is found to be in error in excess of more than ten minutes from that notified to ATS.
optionC: if the average TAS at cruising level varies or is expected to vary by Â±5% from that given in the flight plan.

question: Changing of flight rules from IFR to VFR is possible:
optionA: if instructed by ATC as long as VMC is forecast during the next 60 minutes.
optionC: if instructed by ATC as long as VMC is forecast during the next 30 minutes.

question: During a flight,a change from instrument flight rules (IFR) to visual flight rules (VFR) is only acceptable,when VFR is permitted in that airspace and when:
optionA: the position of the change has been noted on the ATC flight plan. The cancellation of the IFR flight will then be made automatically by ATC.
optionB: the PIC has requested and obtained an ATC CLR for the change and has filed a special VFR flight plan.
optionC: the change is initiated by the PIC with a message containing the specific expression "cancelling my IFR flight".
optionD: ATC invites the PIC to change from IFR to VFR.

question: In the event of a delay for an uncontrolled flight for which an ATS flight plan has been submitted,the flight plan should be amended or a new ATS flight plan submitted and the old one canceled,when the delay exceeds the:

optionA: Yes,but only with permission from ATC.
optionB: No,you have to remain IFR in accordance to the filed flight plan.
optionC: Yes,the pilot in command must inform ATC using the phrase "cancelling my IFR flight".
optionD: No,only ATC can order you to do this.

question: The planned departure time from the parking area is 1815 UTC. The estimated take-off time is 1825 UTC. The IFR flight plan must be filed with ATC at the latest at:
In the event of a delay of a controlled flight,the submitted ATS flight plan should be amended or canceled and a new ATS flight plan submitted when the delay is in excess of:
optionA: 60 minutes of the estimated time of departure.
optionB: 30 minutes of the estimated off-blocks time.
optionC: 60 minutes of the estimated off-blocks time.
optionD: 30 minutes of the estimated time of departure.

question: Pilots of controlled flights are requested to inform the appropriate ATS whenever the average TAS at cruising level between reporting points varies or is expected to vary from the TAS given in the flight plan by:

During an IFR flight TAS and time estimate for the next reporting point appear to deviate from the data in the flight plan. In order to conform to PANS-RAC the deviations should be reported to ATC as soon as they are in excess of:
In the event that a controlled flight inadvertently deviates from its track given in the current ATS Flight Plan,action should be taken in order to:
optionA: Maintain VMC,wait for instructions from the appropriate ATS unit.
optionB: Climb or descent by 500 ft,inform the appropriate ATS unit.
optionC: Notify the appropriate ATS unit immediately notifying the new track and to comply with instructions from ATS.
optionD: Adjust the heading of aircraft to regain track as soon as practicable.

question: Which of the following statements regarding filing a flight plan is correct?
optionA: A flight plan should be filed when a national FIR boundary will be crossed.
optionB: Any flight plan should be filed at least 10 minutes before departure.
optionC: In case of ATFM (Air Traffic Flow Management) the flight plan should be filed at least three hours in advance of the EOBT.
optionD: A flying college can file repetitive flight plan for VFR flights.

question: For flights in accordance with IFR within advisory airspace,an ATS Flight plan:
optionA: shall be submitted. There is no obligation to report changes.
optionB: does not have to be submitted.
optionC: may be submitted at the pilot's discretion. In case a flight plan is submitted,all changes shall be reported as soon as practicable to the appropriate ATS unit.
optionD: shall be submitted. Changes to the flight plan have to be reported.

question: A current flight plan is a:
optionA: flight plan in the course of which radio communication should be practised between aeroplane and ATC.
optionB: filed flight plan with amendments and clearance included.
optionD: flight plan with the correct time of departure.

question: You have a flight plan IFR from Amsterdam to London. In the flight plan it is noted that you will deviate from the ATS route passing the FIR boundary Amsterdam/London. The airway clearance reads "Cleared to London via flight planned route". Which of the following statements is correct?
optionA: It is not allowed to file such a flight plan.
optionB: You will get a separate clearance for the deviation.
optionC: The filed deviation is not accepted.
optionD: The route according to the flight plan is accepted.

question: When an ATS flight plan has been submitted for a controlled flight,the flight plan should be amended or cancelled in the event of the off-block time being delayed by:

Minimum planned take-off fuel is 160 kg. This amount includes a fuel reserve which equals to 30% of the trip fuel. Assume the groundspeed on this trip is constant. When the aeroplane has done half the distance the remaining fuel is 70 kg. Is diversion to a nearby alternate necessary?
optionA: Diversion to a nearby alternate is not necessary,because it is allowed to calculate without reserve fuel.
optionB: Diversion to a nearby alternate is necessary,unless the captain decides to continue on his own responsibility.
optionC: Diversion to a nearby alternate is necessary,because the remaining fuel is not sufficient.
optionD: Diversion to a nearby alternate is not necessary,because the reserve fuel has not been used completely.

Contingency fuel is 5% of the Trip Fuel. The usable fuel at departure is 93 US gallons. At a certain moment the fuel consumed according to the fuel gauges is 40 US gallons and the distance flown is half of the total distance. Assume that fuel consumption does not change. Which statement is right?
optionA: At departure the reserve fuel was 28 US gallons.
optionB: At destination the required reserves remain intact.
optionC: The remaining fuel is not sufficient to reach the destination with reserves intact.
optionD: At the destination there will still be 30 US gallons in the tanks.

question: An aeroplane flies at an airspeed of 380 kts. It flies from A to B and back to A. Distance AB = 480 NM. When going from A to B,it experiences a headwind component = 60 kts. The wind remains constant. The duration of the flight will be:
